body: I had this problem too, but I had this using `st.pyplot()`. I was not able to create a minimal example though. This is preventing me from upgrading to 1.50.0 for now.

I managed to create a minimal example. It seems that it is related to `st.fragment` (or at least it is one of the situations where it occurs):

```python
import streamlit as st
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt

@st.fragment
def frag():
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 3))
    ax.bar([1], [1])
    st.pyplot(fig)

frag()

```
@RR-Rico can you include your code as well? Are you also using fragments?
I was able to reproduce this in conjunction with fragements. A workaround could be to use `width="content"`. In my tests this seems to resolve the issue.
This may have some relation to #11178

@sfc-gh-lwilby Yes it is also inside a container for use. Where could i use `width="content"` 


Our code looks like this:

```

if st.button("Start batch analysis", type="primary"):

    st.subheader("Progress")
    progress = st.progress(0, text="Running Batch Analysis")
    ...
        with st.status("Processing...", expanded=True):
                ...
                progress.progress(
                    percent_complete + 1,
                    text=f"Analyzing {row} ({percent_complete}%)",
                )
                ....
                with st.container(border=True):
                    .....
```
@RR-Rico `st.pyplot(fig, width="content")`. So is all of this a fragment, or the `pyplot` graph is just inside the container?
